bib.title: Fission product yields of 233-U, 235-U, 238-U and 239-Pu in fields of thermal neutrons, fission neutrons and 14.7-MeV neutrons.

free_txt: Determination of the fission yields of U-233, U-235,
U-238, Pu-239 induced by a spectra of fission
par un spectre de neutrons de fission et des neutrons
Goutiere, with experimental details and data.
Data updated and U-233 data added.
Old data were superseded by newer re-analyzed data
SD: New ref. was added. Small corrections
Comment for the ref. 2001BRETTO corrected according to
remark from Dr Granier. REL-REF added.
SD: Comment from Dr  E.Bauge was added.
ERR-ANALYS was updated in all Subents. MISC-COL moved
to Subent 001. Refs on progress reports deleted (no
.For the difference of the neutron flux between the
fission chamber and the target deposits.
.Target and chamber deposits masses are determined by
From Dr E.Bauge: On p.35 of CEA-R report, the
uncertainties are quoted as 2-sigma (we checked that
with the original authors before publishing table III
of the NDS, as well as against internal CEA reports
where more details are given (ref. 3,4,5 in the NDS)).
Plane fission chamber for the measurements
derived from MISC by compiler. Measurement uncertainty
Caliban: mean neutron energy in the cavity is 1.35 MeV.
Prospero-U: mean neutron energy within the cavity is
about 1.25 MeV, outside the assembly - about 0.75 MeV;
neutron flux was 10**11 neutron/cm2/s within the cavity
the number of fissions and of the fission product
the author used to define ERR-1.
The measurement uncertainty is the quadrature sum of
* Statistical error of samples mass ratio (1.-2.%)
* Systematical uncertainty of samples mass ratio(0.8%)
experiment done with accelerator at En=14.7 MeV
Thin deposits ( made by electroplating) - for fission
thicker ones (made by electrospraying) - for fission
.U(3)-O(8) targets on aluminum or titanium foils.
.Pu-O(2) Targets on aluminum or titanium foils.
Target diameter 14 mm, enrichment in Pu-239 better
.U(3)-O(8) Targets on aluminum or titanium foils.
Final value for each fission product is the combination
of these different measurements through weighted
averages, the weight being defined as the inverse of
the square of the statistical uncertainty associated
